verses.verse: (1 A lamentable prayer to God to help the miseries of his Church,8 Desiring him to consider their first estate, when his favor shined toward them, to the intent that he might finish that work which he had begun. ) Hear, O thou shepherd of Israel, thou that leadest Joseph like sheep: show thy brightness, thou that sittest between the Cherubims.
Before Ephraim and Benjamin and Manasseh stir up thy strength, and come to help us.
(Join thy whole people, and all thy tribes together again.) Turn us again, O God, and cause thy face to shine that we may be saved.
O Lord God of hosts, how long wilt thou be (The faithful fear Godâ€™s anger, when they perceive that their prayers are not forthwith heard.) angry against the prayer of thy people?
Thou hast fed them with the bread of tears, and given them tears to drink with great measure.
Thou hast made us a (Our neighbors have continual strife and war against us.) strife unto our neighbors, and our enemies laugh at us among themselves.

(Because that repentance only cometh of God, they most instantly and ofttimes call to God for it as a means whereby they shall be saved.) Turn us again, O God of hosts: cause thy face to shine, and we shall be saved.

Thou hast brought a (Seeing that of thy mercy thou hast made us a most dear possession to thee, and we through our sins are made open for wild beasts to devour us, declare again thy love, and finish the work that thou hast begun.) vine out of Egypt: thou hast cast out the heathen, and planted it.
Thou madest room for it, and didst cause it to take root, and it filled the land.
The mountains were covered with the shadow of it, and the boughs thereof were like the (Hebrew, cedars of God.) goodly cedars.
She stretched out her branches unto the Sea, and her boughs unto the (To wit, Euphrates.) river.
Why hast thou then broken down her hedges, so that all they, which pass by the way, have plucked her?
The wild (That is, as well they that hate our religion, as they that hate our persons.) boar out of the wood hath destroyed it, and the wild beasts of the field have eaten it up.

Return, we beseech thee, O God of hosts: look down (They gave not place to tentation, knowing that albeit there were no help in earth, yet God was able to succor them from heaven.) from heaven and behold, and visit this vine,

And the vineyard, that thy right hand hath planted, and the young vine, which thou madest (So that no power can prevail against it, and which as a young bud thou raisest up again as out of the burnt ashes.) strong for thyself.
It is burnt with fire, and cut down: and they perish at the (Only when thou art angry and not of the sword of the enemy.) rebuke of thy countenance.

Let thine hand be upon the (That is, upon this vine or people, whom thou hast planted with thy right hand, that they should be as one man or one body) man of thy right hand, and upon the son of man, whom thou madest strong for thine own self.

So will not we go back from thee, (For none can call upon God but such as are raised up as it were from death to life, and regenerate by the holy Spirit.) revive thou us, and we shall call upon thy Name.
Turn us again, O Lord God of hosts: cause thy face to shine, and we shall be saved.
